note_text:
OPERATIVE REPORT

INDICATION: The patient presented with radiographic evidence of right lower lobe obstruction.

PROCEDURE: Flexible bronchoscopy with therapeutic aspiration.

NARRATIVE: Following informed consent and the administration of moderate sedation, the bronchoscope was introduced via the left naris. Examination revealed diffuse, erythematous tracheobronchitis accompanied by tenacious, yellow mucous plugging throughout the bronchial tree. Therapeutic aspiration was performed, systematically clearing these secretions from the segmental bronchi. A bronchial wash was obtained from the right lower lobe lateral segment for microbiological analysis. The patient tolerated the procedure well.

note_text: After appropriate consent was obtained the patient was sedated with Fentanyl and Versed and the bronchoscope was inserted. The vocal cords moved normally. Upon entering the trachea mild tracheomalacia was noted along with diffuse tracheobronchitis and thick yellow mucous plugs extending throughout the right and left bronchial trees. Therapeutic aspiration was performed to remove these mucous plugs. Inspection was performed to the subsegmental level. A bronchial wash was performed in the RLL lateral segment. No lesions were seen. The patient tolerated the procedure without complication.

We proceeded to suction these plugs to clear the airways. A specific wash was collected from the right lower lobe. The procedure concluded without adverse events.

note_text:
Dx: Esophageal stent migration to airway.
Anesthesia: GA.
Procedure:
- Flex bronch: Stent visualized blocking distal trachea/LMS. Pus suctioned.
- Rigid bronch (14mm): Inserted.
- Removal: Migrated esophageal stent and clips removed piecemeal (forceps/scissors).
- Repair: TE fistula identified. 13x10x10 Dynamic Y-stent placed to cover defect.
- Airway secured with ETT.
Complications: TE fistula extension.

clinical_context.primary_indication: Left mainstem obstruction secondary to esophageal stent migration
clinical_context.radiographic_findings: Esophageal stent migration through distal trachea and left mainstem

diagnostic_bronchoscopy.inspection_findings: Esophageal stent visualized protruding into trachea 2cm proximal to carina (30% obstruction). Inner covered stent lumen 50% into airway. Outer uncovered stent 5mm into distal left mainstem. Large clip visualized. Purulent secretions.

foreign_body_removal.foreign_body_type: Esophageal stent pieces (covered and uncovered), large clip

cao_interventions_detail.notes: Esophageal stent migration causing obstruction; removed piecemeal using scissors, APC, forceps.
Complete occlusion by migrated stent.

complications.other_complication_details: Extension of TE fistula during stent extraction

outcomes.follow_up_plan_text: CXR in ICU, CT chest prior to extubation. Saline nebulizers 3x/day.

per_code.summary: Y-stent placement typically involves stenting the mainstem bronchi. 31636 is used for the first stented bronchus.
Captures the second limb of the Y-stent in the contralateral mainstem bronchus.
Removal of the migrated esophageal stent and clip constitutes foreign body removal from the airway.

global_comments: Diagnostic bronchoscopy (31622) and lavage (31624/31622) are bundled into the therapeutic codes.
APC and mechanical destruction of the stent were part of the removal process (31635).
Two stent attempts occurred (one failed, one successful); only the successful placement is typically billed.
Y-stent coding varies by payer; 31636/+31637 is commonly used to reflect the bilateral bronchial work, though 31631 (Tracheal) is an alternative.

metadata.notes: Complex case involving esophageal stent removal from airway and Y-stent placement. Fistula extension noted as complication.

note_text: OPERATIVE NARRATIVE: The patient presented with airway obstruction secondary to a migrated esophageal stent. Under general anesthesia, rigid bronchoscopy was utilized. The esophageal prosthesis was found protruding into the distal trachea and occluding the left mainstem. Using rigid forceps and optical scissors, the foreign body was disassembled and extracted piecemeal to relieve the obstruction (CPT 31635). Examination revealed a significant tracheoesophageal fistula. To manage the airway and fistula, a Dynamic Y-stent was deployed, stenting the trachea and bilateral mainstems (CPT 31636, 31637). The airway was secured with an endotracheal tube post-deployment.

Coding Summary:
- 31635: Bronchoscopy with removal of foreign body (Migrated esophageal stent and clips removed via rigid scope).
- 31636: Placement of bronchial stent, initial bronchus (Y-stent tracheal/bronchial limb).
- 31637: Placement of bronchial stent, additional bronchus (Y-stent contralateral limb).
Note: Procedure required rigid bronchoscopy due to complexity and need for piecemeal extraction.

note_text:
Procedure: Rigid Bronchoscopy, FB Removal, Stent Placement.
Indication: Migrated esophageal stent.
Steps:
1. GA induced, LMA placed.
2. Flex bronch showed stent occluding trachea/LMS.
3. Rigid bronch inserted.
4. Foreign body (esophageal stent) removed using forceps and APC.
5. Large TE fistula noted.
6. Dynamic Y-stent deployed to cover fistula and patent airway.
7. ETT placed through stent.

metadata.notes: Complex case involving esophageal stent removal from airway and Y-stent placement. Fistula extension noted as complication.

note_text: Patient has a migrated esophageal stent in the airway causing obstruction so we went to the OR for rigid bronchoscopy. Under GA we saw the stent sticking into the trachea and blocking the left side. We used the rigid scope and forceps to pull the stent out it broke apart so we had to take it out in pieces. There was a big hole between the trachea and esophagus so we put in a Y stent to cover it. It was hard to place but we got it in eventually. Intubated through the stent at the end.

metadata.notes: Complex case involving esophageal stent removal from airway and Y-stent placement. Fistula extension noted as complication.

note_text: Under general anesthesia a therapeutic flexible bronchoscope visualized an esophageal stent protruding into the distal trachea and left mainstem. A 14mm rigid bronchoscope was inserted. The foreign body was removed piecemeal using forceps and scissors. Following removal a large tracheoesophageal fistula was evident. A 13x10x10mm Dynamic Y-stent was deployed to bridge the defect and maintain airway patency involving the trachea and both mainstem bronchi. An ETT was placed through the stent for ventilation.

Left mainstem obstruction via migrated esophageal stent.
[Anesthesia]
General Anesthesia.

Rigid bronchoscopy performed. Esophageal stent found eroding into airway. Foreign body removed piecemeal using rigid techniques. Resultant TE fistula identified. Dynamic Y-stent placed to stent trachea and bilateral bronchi. Airway secured.
[Plan]
ICU monitoring. Keep intubated.

metadata.notes: Complex case involving esophageal stent removal from airway and Y-stent placement. Fistula extension noted as complication.

note_text: We performed a complex airway intervention for a patient with a migrated esophageal stent. Upon inspection, the stent was found compromising the distal trachea and left mainstem. We utilized rigid bronchoscopy to carefully extract the stent fragments and associated clips. This process revealed a significant tracheoesophageal fistula. To restore airway integrity and cover the defect, we deployed a silicone Y-stent, ensuring limbs were seated in the right and left mainstems. The patient was intubated through the stent for post-op management.

note_text:
DIAGNOSIS: Airway blockade due to prosthesis migration.
PROCEDURE: Rigid endoscopy with retrieval of foreign material and prosthetic implantation.
DETAILS: We identified the esophageal device obstructing the airway. Using heavy graspers, we extracted the device in sections. A fistula was noted. We implanted a Y-shaped silicone prosthesis to scaffold the airway and cover the defect. Ventilation was established via an endotracheal tube.

note_text:
Indication: PAP, hypoxia.
Anesthesia: GA, Left DLT.
Procedure:
- DLT placed, isolation confirmed.
- Left Whole Lung Lavage initiated.
- 1L aliquots warm saline instilled/drained.
- Total 8L instilled. Effluent cleared.
- Extubated to NiPPV.
Complications: Transient hypoxia/agitation.

complications.other_complication_details: Post-extubation combativeness and hypoxia requiring ICU admission

note_text: OPERATIVE REPORT: The patient with pulmonary alveolar proteinosis presented for therapeutic whole lung lavage. Following induction of general anesthesia, a left-sided double-lumen tube was placed and position verified bronchoscopically to ensure lung isolation. We proceeded with large-volume lavage of the left lung using warm saline in 1-liter aliquots. Percussion was applied to facilitate clearance. A total of 8 liters was instilled with excellent clearing of the proteinaceous effluent. The patient was extubated and transferred to the ICU.

The procedure was terminated and the patient was extubated and transferred to the ICU for observation of hypoxia.

note_text: The patient underwent a left whole lung lavage for symptomatic pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. We secured the airway with a double-lumen tube to isolate the lungs. We then systematically lavaged the left lung with warm saline, utilizing chest percussion to mobilize the sediment. Initial returns were opaque, but after 8 liters of lavage, the fluid ran clear. We concluded the procedure and transferred the patient to the intensive care unit for post-anesthesia recovery.

note_text: OPERATIVE NARRATIVE: The patient, a pediatric male with a mediastinal mass, presented for airway stent management. Under general anesthesia, bronchoscopy revealed granulation tissue partially obstructing the left mainstem limb of the Y-stent. A rigid bronchoscope was utilized to grasp and extract the Y-stent intact (Foreign Body Removal). Following stent removal, flexible cryotherapy was applied to the residual granulation tissue in the left mainstem to destroy the obstruction (Destruction of Tumor/Stenosis). The airway was patent at the conclusion.

Procedure: Stent Removal, Cryotherapy
Indication: Stent obstruction

2. Flex bronch: Granulation in LMS.
3. Rigid bronch inserted.

5. Flex bronch re-inserted.
6. Cryotherapy (3 cycles) to LMS granulation.
7. Good result.

note_text: We performed a combined rigid and flexible bronchoscopy to manage this patient's airway stent. The Y-stent was found to be obstructed by granulation tissue in the left mainstem. The patient remained stable and was transferred to the pediatric unit.

note_text:
DIAGNOSIS: Stent blockage.
PROCEDURE: Rigid endoscopy for prosthesis retrieval and cryo-ablation.
DETAILS: We accessed the airway and confirmed tissue overgrowth. The Y-prosthesis was gripped and withdrawn using the rigid tube. We then applied freezing energy to the tissue obstructing the left bronchus to clear the passage. The patient recovered without incident.

diagnostic_bronchoscopy.inspection_findings: Vocal cords normal. Subglottic space normal. Y stent in place. No proximal granulation. Thick mucus in stent. RMS normal. LMS distal granulation tissue (30% obstruction).

complications.other_complication_details: Minor bleeding noted during rigid grasping, resolved.

outcomes.follow_up_plan_text: Transfer to PACU then pediatric wards

note_text: OPERATIVE REPORT: The patient with severe tracheobronchomalacia presented with stent obstruction. Rigid bronchoscopy was performed. Initially, copious purulent secretions were aspirated from the lower lobes to clear the airway (Therapeutic Aspiration). The indwelling Y-stent was then grasped and removed intact via the rigid scope (Foreign Body Removal). Inspection revealed granulation tissue causing stenosis in the bilateral mainstems, which was treated with cryotherapy (Destruction of Stenosis). Significant dynamic collapse was noted post-removal.

note_text: Procedure note for stent removal. Patient has TBM and the stent was getting blocked. We put them under GA used the rigid scope. First we had to suck out a ton of pus from the lower lobes it was really thick. Then we grabbed the stent and pulled it out. There was granulation tissue on both sides so we froze it with the cryo probe. Airway collapses a lot without the stent but we are doing a holiday.

Significant tracheobronchomalacia was observed following stent removal. The patient was transferred to the ward for a stent holiday.

note_text: We brought the patient to the OR to manage an obstructed airway stent. Using the rigid bronchoscope, we first cleared significant purulent secretions from the distal airways. We then successfully removed the Y-stent. To address the stenosis caused by granulation tissue at the stent ends, we applied cryotherapy. The airway showed marked collapse consistent with the underlying malacia. We plan to observe the patient without the stent for now.
